title: Is there any way to decompile a .NET assembly or program?
content: Are there any tools available to take an already compiled .dll or .exe file that you know was compiled from C# or Visual Basic and obtain the original source code from it?

comments.text: ILSpy is probably the best choice (IMHO)
Because decompiling .net is very easy most .net code is protected or obfuscated. So in order to use any of the tools suggested in the answer you must remove this protection (if present) first.

answers_data.content: ILSpy is a great open-source decompiler.

comments.text: Combine it with this useful add-on for Visual Studio SourceFly so you can open ILSpy from Visual Studio. Though it doesn't support Visual Studio 2012 in its latest release.

answers_data.content:
I've used JetBrains dotPeek (free of charge) before with some success.

Any JetBrains software I've ever used has been very solid.

It is not quite the 'original source' but it is very readable C# - about the closest thing I would expect to get. Quote from their website:

The last point is free as in free beer, not as in free speech.

Recently I've been using dnSpy [forked from ILSpy by the creator(s) of de4dot] as my main tool for the decompiling and live debugging of .NET code

https://github.com/0xd4d/dnSpy

Main difference from ILSpy :

https://github.com/0xd4d/dnlib

comments.text: How is it different from/better than ILSpy?
This is my first answer, is linking to an external discussion appropriate?   : reddit.com/r/ReverseEngineering/comments/3jau4m/‚Ä¶ ... I will also summarize above.
I can vouch for dnSpy, it think its better than any other similar .NET tool out there. It can even debug the process.
I can really recommend this one. It is the only free tool I found that supports debugging of assembly.
Use it with this Visual Studio extension.

answers_data.content:
There is a free tool available called JustDecompile which does that.

Some features:

comments.text: JustDecompile has a De4Dot Deobfuscator plugin that will help with obfuscated exe

answers_data.content:
I have used .NET Reflector (Note: Commercial, but trial available) several times and quite like it:

http://www.red-gate.com/products/dotnet-development/reflector/

comments.text: Some examples of use cases would be a good addition to this answer. Currently, it is too vague to be of much use besides offering a tool and its website. Giving some real use examples helps define the product a little better.

answers_data.content: If you are interested into a decompiler on API level: https://code.google.com/p/facile-api/ (in Java though)

comments.text: Yeah! I was searching for a java library! Thanks :)
Let me know what you are making ;-) Cheers
I am expecting to add ".NET support" feature to this Disassembler app (github.com/KYHSGeekCode/Android-Disassembler).  :)
Nice, let me know how that works out.

answers_data.content:
I would second the answer about ILSPY as being a really great.net decompiler.  Also, checkout de4dot for deobfuscation.  This is a cool writeup of it in action. 
http://blogs.cisco.com/security/talos/reversing-multilayer-net-malware

Compiled visual basic can be a different and painful animal. 
http://vrt-blog.snort.org/2014/08/discovering-dynamically-loaded-api-in.html?m=1

comments.text: How is compiled Visual Basic (6) related to .NET?
The original question asked about Visual Basic as well.

answers_data.content:
.NET assemblies (.exe and .dll) can be decompiled online at Decompiler.com

The author is affiliated with the mentioned website it appears (username: www.Decompiler.com).

comments.text: "Post good, relevant answers, and if some (but not all) happen to be about your product or website, that‚Äôs okay. However, you must disclose your affiliation in your answers."
